He identified the accused persons present in the dock.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">46.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In cross-examination he denied the suggestion that on 20.03.2004 he did not meet accused Abu Naser and Humayun at the New Market area and he embellished the prosecution story. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">47.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">PW-9 Abdur Rahman deposed that he was an employee of Chittagong KEPZ and accused Naser and Humayun Kabir were also the officers of the said company but they were removed from their service for corruption. On 01.01.2004 Golam Rabbani joined as the Managing Director of the said Company and as a result the said two removed officers became angry to him and they used to threat the Chairman and the Managing Director of the company. On 10.02.2004 the said accused hold a press conference and in the said conference they threatened the chairman of the company Kiha Ko Sang and the authority of the company. As per the direction of the authority he recorded the statements of accused Abu Naser Chowdhury made before the media men. On 11.04.2004 Golam Rabbani received bullet injury while he was going to the site. He believed that the said accused persons committed the above offence. Eventually, he heard accused Naser, Humayun, Sohel, Selim, Hashem and other accused persons committed the said offence.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">48.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In cross-examination he stated that in KEPZ there were 10-12 Sub-Assistant Engineer (SAE). He heard that accused Naser was removed from his service due to corruption but no one made any complain against accused Naser to him. He proved the said statements as exhibit-5(Ka), 5(Kha) and 5(Ga) and his signature’s thereon as exhibit-4(Ka)1/2.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">52.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In cross-examination he stated that witness Forkan and Arman did not disclose the father’s name and addresses of the accused persons. He had no knowledge about the application dated 29.05.2004 submitted by the accused Saiful.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; line-height: 110%;">56.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; Sadek deposed that he was a driver of KEPZ and he on 11.04.2004 at about 10.00 AM being the driver of the vehicle Chattra-Metro Cha-510113 started for KEPZ with Commodore Golam Rabbani, Engineer Imtiaj, Engineer Abul Kamal Azad, Engineer Parvej and Engineer Zakir. When they crossed Muradpur crossing then a local bus came before his vehicle and he gave horn and at that time 5/6 young persons came to their vehicle and asked to handover money bags and mobiles and the miscreants took away money, mobile phones and the official documents and at one stage they opened gunshot and left the place by a green car. At the time of leaving the scene, the miscreants were telling that they killed the main officer of the KEPZ. They taking injured Commodore Golam Rabbni rushed to Chittagong Medical College Hospital. He made the said statement before the Magistrate as well as the investigating officer. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">58.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In cross-examination by accused Abu Naser he could not memorize the date of his statement made before the Magistrate and he could also not remember whether he stated before the Magistrate that the miscreants told that they killed the main man of the KEPZ. The miscreants snatched the key of the vehicle. The miscreants did not take anything from him. He denied the defence suggestion that he deposed falsely.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">59.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">PW-14 Wahidul Islam Khan deposed that while he was serving as a Magistrate of Metropolitan Magistracy in Chittagong Court, he on 10.05.2004 recorded the statement of witness Md. text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">94.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">     <span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">   </span></span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">In cross-examination PW-9 categorically denied the defence suggestions that he did not present in the press conference and record the statement of the accused Abu Naser and accused Humayun was not present in the press conference.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">95.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">PW-13 Mohammad Sadek who was driving the vehicle at the time of the incident deposed that: </span></span><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: MoinaNormal;">""k¡h¡l f§­hÑ p¿»¡p£l¡ h­m ®LC¢f­S­Xl Bpm LjÑLaÑ¡ M¤e L¢lu¡¢Rz''<span style="mso-spacerun: yes;">  </span></span></strong></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><strong style="mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-bidi-font-family: 'Times New Roman';"><span style="mso-list: Ignore;">96.<span style="font: 7.0pt 'Times New Roman';">        </span></span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">If we carefully analyze the above assertions of prosecution witnesses it is cristal clear that accused Abu Naser Chowdhury and Humayun Kabir, who were removed from the service of KEPZ by the authority for alleged corruption and their activates against the KEPZ, hatched conspiracy against the management of KEPZ including its Chairman Kiha Ko Sang and Commodore Golam Rabbani who joined as the Managing Director of the company after their removal. And as a result of their conspiracy Commodore Golam Rabbani was killed by them with the help of hired criminals. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">97.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">It is true that the prosecution was failed to adduce any direct evidence that accused Abu Naser Chowdhury and Humayun Kabir hired the other accused persons in order to kill Commodore Golam Rabbani. But section 120B of the Penal Code provides the punishment for criminal conspiracy; which criminal conspiracy is defined in section 120A of the Penal Code which runs as follows:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">“120A. Definition of Criminal conspiracy-</span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> when two or more persons agree to do, or (1) an illegal act, or</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">(2) An act which is not illegal by illegal means, such an agreement is designated a criminal conspiracy:</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Provided that no agreement except an agreement to commit an offence shall amount to a criminal conspiracy unless some act besides the agreement is done by one or more parties to such agreement in pursuance thereof. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Explanation- it is immaterial whether the illegal act is the ultimate object of such agreement, or is merely incidental to that object.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">The recognized definition of a criminal conspiracy is an agreement between two or more persons to engage in an unlawful act. ‘Conspiracy’ an inchoate offence, refers to an act of agreeing to commit a substantive crime to further plan and policy.”</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">98.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Here we have to emphasis, ‘Conspiracy’, an inchoate offence, refers to an act of agreeing to commit a substantive crime to further plan and policy.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">99.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The criminal conspiracy doctrine only requires overlapping chains of agreement that link the physical perpetrator to the accused. However, the lack of a direct agreement between the physical perpetrator and other accused persons is no bar to applying the conspiracy doctrine as long as the chain of overlapping agreements connects them.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">100.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The act of ‘agreement’ is to be inferred from act conduct of the accused-amid, prior or subsequent to the commission of the principal offence. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">101.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In the case of <strong>Major Bazlul Huda vs. State [Popularly known as Bangabandhu murder case]</strong> his Lordships Justice S.K. Sinha <strong>[62 DLR (AD), page-1; para 173]</strong> has observed to the effect:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">“An act or illegal omission must take place in pursuance of the conspiracy and in order to the doing of the thing conspired for; in the latter offence the mere agreement is enough, if the agreement is to commit an offence. In pursuance of the criminal conspiracy if the conspirators commit several offences, then all of them will be liable for the offences even if some of them had not actively participated in the commission of the offences. It is not required to prove that each and every person who is a party to the conspiracy must do some overt act towards the fulfillment of the object of conspiracy, <u>the essential ingredient being an agreement between the conspirators to commit the crime since form its very nature a conspiracy is hatched in secrecy direct evidence of a criminal conspiracy to commit a crime is not available otherwise the whole purpose may frustrate in most cases only the circumstantial evidence which is available from which an inference giving rise to the commission of an offence of conspiracy may be legitimately drawn.”</u> [Underline to emphasis]</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">102.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">It is now well settled that it is not required to prove that each and every persons who is a party to the conspiracy must do some overt act towards the fulfillment of object of the conspiracy. The essential ingredient being an agreement between the conspirators to commit crime since from its very nature a conspiracy is hatched in secrecy direct evidence of a criminal conspiracy to commit a crime may not be available. The circumstantial evidence which is available from which an inference giving rise to the commission of offence may be legitimately drawn. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">103.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the case of <strong>State of H.P. vs. Krishan Lal Pardhan, reported in (1987) 2 SCC, page-17</strong>, it has been held that: </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">“In the opinion of Special Judge every one of the conspirators must have taken active part in commission of each and every one of the conspiratorial acts and only then the offence of conspiracy will be made out. Such a view is clearly wrong. The offence of criminal conspiracy consists in a meeting of minds of two or more persons or agreeing to do or causing to be done an illegal act or an act by illegal means, and the performance of an act in terms thereof. If pursuant to the criminal conspiracy the conspirators commit several offences, then all of them will be liable for the offences even if some of them had not actively participated in the commission of the offences.”</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">104.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In the case of <strong>State of Maharashtra vs. Som Nath Thapa, reported in (1996) 4 SCC, Page-259, </strong>it has been held that<strong>:</strong></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">“To establish a charge of conspiracy knowledge about indulgence in either an illegal act or a legal act by illegal means is necessary. In some cases, intent of unlawful use being made of the goods or services in question may be inferred from the knowledge itself. This apart, the prosecution has not to establish that a particular unlawful use was intended, so long as the goods or service in question could not be put to any lawful use. <u>Finally, when the ultimate offence consists of a chain of actions, it would not be necessary for the prosecution to establish, to bring home the charge of conspiracy, that each of the conspirators had the knowledge of what the collaborator would do, so long as it is known that the collaborator would put the goods or service to an unlawful use. . . . . . . .</u>”</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Where in pursuance of the agreement the conspirators commit offences individually or adopt illegal means to do a legal act which has a nexus to the object of conspiracy, all of them will be liable for such offences even if some of them have not actively participated in the commission of those offences.</span></u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> [Underline to emphasis]</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">105.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the case of <strong>Yash Pal Mittal vs. State of Panjub, reported in (1977) 4 SCC, page-540</strong>, it has been held that:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">“9. The offence of criminal conspiracy under section 120-A is a distinct offence introduced for the first time in 1913 in Chapter V-A of the Penal Code. The very agreement, concert or league is the ingredient of the offence. It is not necessary that all the conspirators must know each and every detail of the conspiracy as long as they are co-participators in the main object of the conspiracy. There may be so many devices and techniques adopted to achieve the common goal of the conspiracy and there may be division of performances in the chain of actions with one object to achieve the real end of which every collaborator must be aware and in which each one of them must be interested. There must be unity of object or purpose but there may be plurality of means sometimes even unknown to one another, amongst the conspirators. In achieving the goal several offences may be committed by some of the conspirators even unknown to the others. The only relevant factor is that all means adopted and illegal acts done must be and purported to be in furtherance of the object of the conspiracy even though there may be sometimes misfire or overshooting by some of the conspirators. Even if some steps are restored to by one or two of the conspirators without the knowledge of the others it will not affect the culpability of those others when they are associated with the object of the conspiracy. The significance of criminal conspiracy under section 120-A is brought out pithily by this Court in Major E.G. Barsay Vs. State of Bombay thus:</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">‘The gist of the offence is an agreement to break the law. The parties to such an agreement will be guilty of criminal conspiracy, though the illegal act agreed to be done has not been done. So too, it is not an ingredient of the offence that all the parties should agree to do a single illegal act. It may comprise the commission of a number of acts. Under section 43 of the Indian Penal Code, an act would be illegal if it is an offence or if it is prohibited by law. Under the first charge the accused are charged with having conspired to do three categories of illegal acts, and the mere fact that all of them could not be convicted separately in respect of each of the offences has no relevancy in considering the question whether the offence of conspiracy has been committed. They are all guilty of the offence of conspiracy to do illegal acts, though for individual offences all of them may not be liable.’</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">106.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">If we consider the above of proposition law coupled with the evidence on record and the facts and circumstances of the present case, we are of the view that the learned Judge of the Druta Bichar Tribunal rightly and lawfully found guilty to accused Abu Naser Chowdhury and Humayun Kabir for committing Criminal Conspiracy in committing murder of the decease under section 120B/302 of the Penal Code. However, the learned Judge has committed an error in awarding lesser sentence to accused Abu Naser and Humayun Kabir; the learned judge awarded an inadequate sentence of five years against them having though there is a provision of capital punishment or imprisonment for life under section 120B of the Penal Code for the same offence. However, nothing has been elaborately discussed in the impugned judgment about to such minor punishment. In view of the evidence, facts and circumstances as remained in the case and the discussions made herein above, we are in a considered view that the said punishment awarded by the trial court should have to be altered and enhanced.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">107.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The learned Judge of the Druta Bichar Tribunal convicted accused Salim, Hashem and Sohel under section 302 of the Penal Code and acquitted accused Saiful Islam alias Saiful from the charges brought against him.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">108.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Accused Salim was identified in TI parade by pw-3 Abul Kalam Azad. And PW-11 Magistrate Shafiqur Rahman categorically testified that he conducted the TI parade on 8.06.2004 and witness Abul Kalam Azad could identify accused Salim. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">109.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">From the evidence it further revels that accused Saiful Islam alias Belai Saiful was also identified by P.W-1 A.K.M Emtajul Islam in TI parade in presence of P.W-11 Shafiqur Rahman, the Magistrate who conducted the T.I. Parade despite he was acquitted by the Tribunal.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">110.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The Tribunal in acquitting accused Saiful held that the other witnesses who accompanied the deceased at the time of occurrence with P.W.-1 could not identify accused Saiful in T.I Parade and accused Saiful raised objection by filing written objection against the order of IT Parade. Moreover, the Tribunal also held that the identification of Saiful was not proved beyond doubt.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">111.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the instant case accused Saiful in the midst of the trial having obtained bail from a Division Bench of this Court absconded and ultimately did not face the trial.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">112.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">It is true that abscondence of an accused is not conclusive proof of his guilty and cannot be the sole basis of his conviction without and corroborative evidence.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">113.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">However, in the instant case accused Saiful was identified in TI parade by P.W-1, which was conducted by a Magistrate P.W-11. And after obtaining bail he was absconded and did not face the trial to defend himself. This circumstance furnished strong corroboration to the prosecution case that he is the culprit and it may lend weight to TI parade. Thus, the Tribunal most illegally acquitted accused Saiful alias Belai Saiful.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">114.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In the instant case we do not find any creadible evidence against convict Sohel alias Abdul Malek to convict him under section 302/34 of the Penal Code. No TI parade was held in respect of him. Identification in the dock by PW-3 in absence of any other corroborative evidence cannot be considered as reliable evidence. The learned Judge of the Druta Bichar Tribunal in finding his guilt in this particular case had considered his other criminal cases which cannot be appreciated. Thus, we are of the opinion that the Tribunal committed serious illegality in convicting the accused Sohel and he is liable to be acquitted.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">115.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">It is pertinent to mention here that convict Hasem has been acquitted in the meantime in Criminal Appeal No.1814 of 2005 by a Division Bench of this Court. Hearing of the said appeal alone is no doubt beyond the norms, partice and rule of this Court. The State also did not take any step against such unusual hearing of the said appeal and as well as the said judgment.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">116.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Having discussed and considered as above Criminal Appeal Nos.1669 of 2005, 1798 of 2005, 1614 of 2005 are dismissed and both the Rules in Criminal Revision No.1105 and 855 of 2005 are made absolute. However, Criminal Appeal No.1785 of 2005 is allowed. </span><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">117.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Resultantly the conviction of accused Humayun Kabir Chowhdury and Abu Naser Chowhury under section 120B/302 of the Penal Code is hereby affirmed but their sentences are enhanced to suffer imprisonment for life with a fine of Taka 50,000/- (Fifty thousand) instead of 05(five) years. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">118.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Beside, conviction and sentence of accused Md. Salim passed by the Druta Bichar Tribunal, Chittagong is hereby affirmed. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">119.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">However, the judgment and order of acquittal, so for as it relates to accused Saiful Islam alias Bilai Saiful, is set aside. The Trial Court is directed to pass a fresh judgment in light of the observations made in the body of this judgment. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">120.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The convicts Humayun Kabir, Abu Naser Chowdhury, Md. Salim who are on bail are directed to surrender before the trial Court within 08(Eight) weeks from the date of receipt of this judgment and order to serve out their respective sentence.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">121.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Accused Sohel alias Abdul Malek Shohel is hereby acquitted from the charges brought against him and he is set at liberty at once, if not wanted in any other case.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">122.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Accused Saiful Islam alias Saiful alias Bilai Saiful is also directed to surrender before the Trial Court within the period of 08(Eight) weeks from the date of receipt of this judgment and order. The trial Court is at liberty to consider his prayer for bail, if, he surrenders complying the Court’s order keeping in mind that earlier he was acquitted in the case.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">123.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">    </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Send down the lower court records at once.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">         Ed. </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"> </span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt; letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">Criminal Appeal No. 1669 of 2005 </span></a><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt; letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">with </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10pt; letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">Criminal Appeal No. 1798 of 2005 <strong>with</strong>  Criminal Appeal No. 1614 of 2005 <strong>with</strong>  Criminal Appeal No. 1785 of 2005 <strong>with</strong> Criminal Revision No. 1105 of 2005 <strong>with</strong>  Criminal Revision No. 855 of 2005.</span></span></p></div></div></div></div>

No. 229/15)</span></em></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>Article 102</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.85pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>Whatever observations the High Court Division wanted to make in the context, it could make so before its final decision </strong><strong><span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">if those were necessary for the disposal of</span></strong> <strong><span style="letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">the writ petition or in giving relief to the writ</span></strong> <strong><span style="letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">petitioners in the facts and circumstances</span></strong><strong> of the case, but not after the disposal of the </strong><strong><span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">rule.</span></strong> <strong><span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">We are of the further view that justice</span></strong><strong> would be best served if the quoted observations are expunged accordingly those are expunged. . . .(9 and 10)</strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.85pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">: </span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. A. F. Hasan Arif, Senior Advocate, Instructed by Mr. Zainul Abedin, Advocate-on-record. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.85pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.2pt;">: </span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr Khaliur Rahman, Advocate, Instructed <span style="letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">by Mr. Zahirul Islam, Advocate</span>-on-record. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.85pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">: </span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Not represented.  </span></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">JUDGMENT</span></u></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%; margin: 12.0pt 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-variant: small-caps;">Md. Abdul wahhab miah, j</span></u></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-variant: small-caps;">:</span></strong> <span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">These two civil appeals (C.A), by leave are from a common Judgment and order dated 15-04-13 passed by the High Court Division in petition Nos.17056 and 17216 of 2012 making the Rule Nisi issued in the respective Writ petition absolute.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 12.0pt 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Respondent Nos.1-4 of C.A. No.228 and  Responden Nos.1 and 2 of C.A. No.229 of 2015 as the petitioners respectively filed Writ petition Nos.17056 and 17216 of 2012 before the High Court Division challenging Memo No.B.R–Dhaka 98/98/792 dated 01.10.2012, and Memo No. B.R-Dhaka 98/98/799 dated 02.10.2012, both issued by writ Respondent No.4, Manager Court of Wards, Bhawal Raj Estate Dhaka requesting respondent No.5, the Registar Dhaka not to  register any deed of transfer / sale of any property of C. S. Plot Nos. 2497, and 2582 of C.S Khation No. 118 of Mouza  Baunia J. L. No.211 as found at page 510 of projabili property Gazette (Annexure C to the Writ petition) corresponding to S .A. Khation Nos. 118/ 76, 183, 184, 188, 198, 212. 220, 1747, 179, 118/2, and 234 corresponding to R.S. plot Nos. 6108, 6109, 6112 and 6116, of R. S. Khation Nos. 63, 116, 117, 181, 240, 811, 818, 819, 962, 1083, 1371, 1490 and 1589 and C. S. Plot Nos. 2035, 2106, 2137, 2142, 2151, 2176, 2972, 2976, 2977, 2987, 3280, 3290, and 2977/3459 recorded in C.S. Khation Nos.554, 555 and C.S . Plot Nos. 2748 and 2970 of C. S. Khation Nos. 118, C. S. Khation Nos. 3280/3438 of C.S. Khation No.646 and C.S. plot No.3279 of C.S. Khation Nos.12 of Mouza Baunia of J. L. No.211 along with some other properties of other plots of the aforesaid Khations corresponding to as many as 66 R. S. plots respectively (Plots are not mentioned as those Would not be necessary in disposing the appeals) to have been issued without lawful authority and were of no legal effect and accordingly the Rule Nisi Was issued in the respective writ petition. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 12.0pt 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The writ petitions were contested by writ respondent Nos.3 and 4 by filing affidavit-in-opposition.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 12.0pt 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The High Court Division hearing the parties by the impugned judgment and order made the rule Nisi Issued in The respective writ petition absolute and then made certain observations  With caution to the Land Reform Board and Court of Wards (writ respondent Nos. 3 and 4).</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 12.0pt 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Being aggrieved by and dissatisfied with the impugned judgment and order passed in the respective writ petition Civil petition for Leave to appeal Nos. 2200 and 2201 of 2013 resection, were filed before this Division by writ respondent Nos.3 and 4 and leave was granted giving rise to these two C.As.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Hasan Arif, Learned Advocate for the appellants at the very outset Submits that he would not press the grounds on which leave was granted, But he would press very much for expunging the observation made by the High Court Division in the impugned   judgment to the effect:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">“If in future any such illegal and uncalled for claim is sought for by the court of wards or if any litigation is continuing or started afresh because of court of wards action by claiming title over the said “projabili property “by the Court of Wards and the land reform Board then they would be liable to be dealt with for contempt of Court, apart from such litigations been (sic) abated under P.O.90of 1972.</span></p><p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Under such circumstances we think it would proper to call the Manger court of wards and the land Administrator to explain their position in the respect because the government officials   under no circumstances can play with the property of the general peoples. This court thus thought that exercising the power conferred under the law we   should   call the said officials to explain their conduct as to these two cases in particular.  But considering that it will be nothing but a future exercise of this court on the matter,   because when the   respondents could not come forward with a proper affidavit giving proper explanations supported by the papers, we simply can express our anxiety and great concern that the Government official are doing this only to harass the general people of the country and thereby they are trying to have some personal gain over it.  As   such the respondents No.3 and   4 are cautioned not to deal with such property of the general people in such mannter which can be subject matter of harassment of the general people”</span></p><p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">He submits that the quoted observations were made unnecessarily out of the context after the Rules were made absolute.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNoSpacing" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">Mr. Khalilur Rahman, learned Advocate for respondent Nos.1-4 in both the appeals found it difficult to resist the submission of Mr. Hassan Arif.</span></span></p><p class="MsoHeading7" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">From the impugned judgment, it appears that the observations quoted hereinbefore, were made absolute finding in clear terms the impugned Memos to have been issued without lawful authority and were of no legal effect. We are of the view that whatever observations the High Court. Division wanted to make in the context, it could make so before its final decision if those were necessary for the disposal of the writ petition or in giving relief to the writ petitioners in the facts and circumstances of the case, but not after the disposal of the rule. And then again no observation could be made pre-empting the future action (s) or future behavior of the writ respondents.  A  Court has right to make observation  (s)  about the behavior or action of the writ respondent (s) in future, particularly, about the possible disobedience or violation of the order/direction/observation of the Court, the reason being that when  a Court presumed that such order/direction /observation shall be obeyed and complied with in its true purport <span style="letter-spacing: 0.3pt;">and spirit. And if the Court itself nurishes an</span> <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">element of doubt in its mind as to the obedience</span> or the compliance with its order/direction/ observation, then there cannot have any meaning in passing such order/giving such direction /making such observation. And such kind of doubt by a court shall make the people’s confidence in the administration of justice shaky. We would like to add further that a Court must always pass an order/give/ direction/and make observation in a positive way to ensure fair justice and not in a manner quoted hereinbefore.</span></p><p class="MsoHeading7" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: none; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 12.0pt 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In view of the   above, our considered view is that the High Court Division was not justified in making the quoted observations after making the Rule Nisi absolute declaring the impugned Memos to have been issued without lawful authority and were of no legal effect. We are of the further view that justice would be best served if the quoted observations are expunged accordingly those are expunged.</span></span></p><p class="MsoHeading7" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">         </span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The appeals are disposed of with the above expunction</span></span></p><p class="Default" style="text-indent: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN">Ed. </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoHeading7" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: none; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN"> </span></strong></span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-variant: small-caps;">Civil App</span></u></strong></a><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-variant: small-caps;">eal No. 228- 229 Of 2015</span></u></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 9pt;">(From the Judgment order dated 15-04-13 passed by the High Court Division in Writ Petition Nos. 17056 and of 17216 of 2012).</span></span></p></div></div></div></div>
