line-height: 110%;">Judgment on</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-align: center; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in -6.4pt 6.0pt .7pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">22.08.2017</span></strong></span></p></td><td style="width: 36px; padding: 0in 5.4pt; height: 27pt;" width="21"><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: center; line-height: 150%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">}</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: center; line-height: 150%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">}</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: center; line-height: 150%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">}</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftn1" name="_ftnref1" title=""><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">}</span></strong></span></a></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">}</span></strong></span></p></td><td style="width: 136px; padding: 0in 5.4pt; height: 27pt;" width="125"><p class="CM11" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in .0001pt -.7pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Md. Azizul Haque</span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="CM11" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt -.7pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">. . .<u>Appellant</u></span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="Default" style="text-align: center; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt -.7pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: windowtext;">=Versus=</span></strong></span></p><p class="Default" style="margin-left: -.7pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: windowtext;">Grameen Bank and others </span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="Default" style="margin-left: -.7pt; text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: windowtext;">. . . <u>Respondents</u></span></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.6pt;">Administrative Tribunal Act, 1980 (VII of 1981)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 4(2)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.85pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The termination of the appellant was a “termination </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">simpliciter</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">” without attaching any stigma and that in fact no departmental proceedings were brought against the appellant in spite of serious allegations against him. In such a situation it would be illogical to sustain the order of the Administrative Tribunal thereby reinstating the appellant in service on an unwilling employer. Admittedly, the appellant was entitled to get 3 months’ salary in lieu of notice. The Administrative Appellate Tribunal, therefore, rightly allowed the appeal in part setting aside the judgement of the Administrative Tribunal. In the facts and circumstances of the case, at our instance, Mr. Abdur Razzak Khan has agreed to instruct the Grameen Bank to pay the appellant 2 years’ salary in order to bring this matter to a close. The respondent Grameen Bank is hereby directed to pay the appellant Md. Azizul Haque salary for two years at the rate which was paid to him as on the date of his termination of service.         </span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: right; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.85pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">. . .(10, 11 and 13)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">For the Appellant: </span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Mr. Sk. Mohammed</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> Morshed Advocate, instructed by, Mr. Md. Zahirul Islam, Advocate-on-Record</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; margin: 0in 0in .25in 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">For the Respondents:</span></strong> <span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">Mr. Abdur Razzak</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> Khan, Senior Advocate, instructed by, Mr. Taufique Hossain, Advocate-on-Record</span></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">JUDGMENT</span></u></strong></span></p><h4 style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-variant: small-caps;">Muhammad Imman Ali, J</span></u><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-variant: small-caps;">:</span></u> <span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-weight: normal;">This civil appeal, by leave, is directed against the order dated </span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-weight: normal;">06.08.2009 passed by the Administrative Appellate Tribunal, Dhaka in A.A.T. Appeal No.218 of 2005 allowing the appeal, thereby setting aside the order dated 30.10.2005 passed by the Administrative Tribunal, Bogra, in A.T. Case No. 84 of 2004.</span></span></h4><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span class="FontStyle17"><strong><span style="line-height: 110%;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong></span>Facts of the case, in brief, are that the <span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">appellant herein filed Administrative Tribunal Case No.84 of 2004 in the Administrative Tribunal, Bogra, challenging the order of his termination  from service. The appellant stated, <em>inter alia,</em> that he was appointed as a ‘Bank Worker’ in the Grameen Bank on 28.02.1990 and his appointment was made permanent on 19.09.1991. Subsequently, he was promoted to the post of Upper Division Assistant on 04.10.1994. On his satisfactory performance in service he was promoted to Upper Division Assistant (Senior) on 06.10.1997. Eventually on 04.11.2001, he was promoted to the rank of officer in the bank. On 06.05.2002, he filed an application to go on voluntary retirement, but the said application remained un-disposed for </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">a </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">long time. On 11.05.2004, the bank authority illegally terminated his service without any cause. He preferred a departmental appeal praying for giving him termination benefits. Subsequently, he made two more representations to the authority for reinstating him in service, but to no avail. Thus, </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">he was </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">compelled to file the case before the Administrative Tribunal, Bogra under section 4(2) of </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">the </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">Administrative Tribunals Act, 1980.</span></span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span class="FontStyle14"><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">Respondents No.2 and 3 contested the administrative tribunal case by filing written </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">statement denying </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">the </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">material </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">allegations of the appellant </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">contending, <em>inter </em></span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><em><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">alia</span></em></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">, that the authority rightly </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">terminated </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">his </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">service under Rule </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">13 of the Grameen </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">Bank Service Rules, </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">1993 </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">and </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">the said order suffers </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">from </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">no illegality, and as such the case was liable to </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">be rejected.</span></span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span class="FontStyle17"><strong><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">After hearing the parties, the Administrative Tribunal, Bogra, by the order dated 30.10.2005 allowed A.T. Case No.84 of 2004 holding that the termination of the appellant from </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">service </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 12pt; line-height: 110%;">without giving him either three months' notice or three months' salary and other financial benefits as per Rule 13 of the Grameen Bank Employees Service Rules was illegal.</span></span></span></p><p class="Style2" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span class="FontStyle14"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Being aggrieved, the present respondents preferred Administrative Appeal No.218 of 2005 before the Administrative Appellate Tribunal, Dhaka, and  after hearing the parties and considering the facts and circumstances of the case, the Administrative Appellate Tribunal </span></span><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">allowed the appeal in part setting aside the judgement and order of the Administrative Tribunal, Bogra maintaining the termination order dated 11.05.2004 and directing the Grameen Bank authority to pay the petitioner  Md.  Azizul  Haque 3 months' salary and other attendant financial benefits within 2(two) months, as admissible under the provisions of </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Rule 13 of </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">the Grameen Bank  Employees Service Regulations, </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">1993 </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">together with a sum of Tk.</span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">10,000/- </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">as cost of the litigation and Tk. </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">10,000/- </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">as compensation to the petitioner, in total Tk.</span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">20,000/-only.</span></span></span></p><p class="Style2" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Being aggrieved, the appellant filed Civil Petition for Leave to Appeal No.1833 of 2009 and l</span></span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">eave was granted to consider the following submissions of the learned advocate</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> appearing for the petitioner</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">: </span></span></p><p class="Style5" style="text-align: justify; line-height: normal; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.35pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">   “I. That the Administrative Appellate  Tribunal was wrong in maintaining the impugned order of termination on making observation to the effect that no useful purpose will be served by reinstating the petitioner on an unwilling employer, as this rule is applicable in cases of master and servant </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">relationship, </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">but in the instant case, Grameen Bank having been established by a statute namely, Grameen Bank Ordinance, </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">1983 and the </span></span><span class="FontStyle15"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">terms and conditions of the service of its </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">employees being governed by statutory rules namely, Grameen Bank Employees Service Regulations, the relationship between Grameen Bank and its employees is not one of master and servant. </span></span></span></p><p class="Style5" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.35pt;"><span class="FontStyle17" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">II. That Rule 13 of the Grameen Bank Employees Service Regulations, 1993 clearly provides that an employee can be terminated from service either on giving him three months' notice or on payment of three months' salary and other attendant financial benefits, but in this case, admittedly the authority did not either give the petitioner three months' notice or three months' salary or other attendant financial benefits before terminating the petitioner from service and even did not disclose anything about payment of three months' salary and other attendant financial benefits before filing of this case by the petitioner before the Administrative Tribunal and in the circumstances the Administrative Tribunal rightly declared the termination order illegal. </span></span></p><p class="Style5" style="text-align: justify; line-height: normal; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.35pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">III. That the Administrative Appellate Tribunal though found the impugned </span></span><span class="FontStyle20"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">termination order </span></span><span class="FontStyle17"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">illegal for the reasons of non-service of three months' notice or non-payment of three months' salary and other attendant financial benefits as per Rule 13 of the Grameen Bank Employees Service Regulations, 1993, but wrongly maintained the impugned termination order on an erroneous notion. </span></span></span></p><p class="Style5" style="text-align: justify; line-height: normal; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 27.35pt;"><span class="FontStyle17" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">IV. That the Administrative Appellate Tribunal committed illegality in maintaining the impugned termination order while it itself found the impugned termination order illegal. </span></span></p><p class="Style5" style="text-align: justify; line-height: normal; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 27.0pt;"><span class="FontStyle17" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">V. That the impugned termination order being illegal there was no scope to maintain that order by the Administrative Appellate Tribunal.”</span></span></p><p class="Style2" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Sk. Mohammad Morshed appearing for the appellant made submissions in line with the grounds upon which leave was granted. He also submitted that the appellant submitted an application for retirement from service on 06.5.2002 after having served Grameen Bank for more than 12 years and he is entitled to get pension. That application has not been disposed of with <em>mala fide</em> intention and Grameen Bank served notice of termination on 11.5.2004. The learned Advocate submitted that the Administrative Tribunal rightly directed the employer, Grameen Bank to reinstate the appellant and Grameen Bank has terminated the appellant only with intention to deprive him from getting pension and other benefits.     </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></strong>Mr. Abdur Razzak Khan, learned Senior Advocate appearing on behalf of the Grameen Bank submitted that the allegations brought against the appellant are of a serious and intimate nature and because of the delicate nature of the allegations involving a female employee, Grameen Bank decided to terminate the service of the appellant instead of starting departmental proceedings against him. The learned Advocate further submitted that the employer was willing to pay the requisite 3 months’ salary in lieu of notice and attendant financial benefits to the appellant. </span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></strong>We have considered the submissions of the learned Advocates for the parties concerned, perused the impugned order as well as the evidence and materials on record.</span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: normal; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></strong>We find that the termination of the appellant was a “termination simpliciter” without attaching any stigma and that in fact no departmental proceedings were brought against the appellant in spite of serious allegations against him. In such a situation it would be illogical to sustain the order of the Administrative Tribunal thereby reinstating the appellant in service on an unwilling employer. Admittedly, the appellant was entitled to get 3 months’ salary in lieu of notice. The Administrative Appellate Tribunal, therefore, rightly allowed the appeal in part setting aside the judgement of the Administrative Tribunal. </span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: normal; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>11.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></strong>In the facts and circumstances of the case, at our instance, Mr. Abdur Razzak Khan has agreed to instruct the Grameen Bank to pay the appellant 2 years’ salary in order to bring this matter to a close. </span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: normal; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>12.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></strong>In view of the discussion above, we are of the opinion that justice will best be served if the appeal is disposed of in the following terms:</span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: normal; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>13.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></strong>The respondent Grameen Bank is hereby directed to pay the appellant Md. Azizul Haque salary for two years at the rate which was paid to him as on the date of his termination of service.</span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; line-height: normal; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">         Accordingly, with the above direction, the appeal is disposed of, without, however, any order as to costs. The impugned order of the Administrative Appellate Tribunal is modified, as stated above.</span></p><p class="Default" style="text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Ed. </span></strong></span></p><p class="Style2" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"> </span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><u><span style="font-size: 10pt; font-variant: small-caps;">Civil Appeal No. 26 of  2014</span></u></strong></a><u></u></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 9pt;">(From the order dated 6<sup>th</sup> of August, 2009 passed by the Administrative Appellate Tribunal, Dhaka, in A.A.T. Appeal No.218 of 2005). </span></span></p></div></div></div></div>

Mamun @ Walid Hasan</span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . Convict-<u>Petitioner</u></span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: right; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 110%;">(On bail)</span></em></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">-Versus-</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The State</span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">...Opposite-Party</span></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Words and Phrases </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Conviction </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Literally the word ‘Conviction’ means the firm belief of a person in something. In our legal system, the term ‘Conviction’ is the outcome of the criminal prosecution that culminates in a decision of the Court. Conviction represents one of two possibilities that typically arise at the end of a criminal proceeding: either the accused will be found guilty or not guilty of the crime with which he/she is charged. Usually Conviction is perceived by the people as the state of being found or proven guilty or the act of proving or declaring a person guilty of a crime.          . . .(11)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Words and Phrases </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Conviction </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Convictions are associated with criminal proceedings, as opposed to civil proceedings. Our criminal jurisprudence requires that to secure a Conviction, the prosecution has to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused committed the offence.                     . . .(11)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Words and Phrases </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Sentence </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">The word ‘Sentence’ is traditionally defined </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">as the judicial determination and pronouncement</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> of a punishment to be imposed on a person convicted of a crime. Once the accused has been found guilty of a crime, or rather convicted, the Court or Judge will formally declare the appropriate punishment to be imposed upon the person. The Court orders </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">a Sentence based on the relevant law applicable</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> to the particular crime.</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Words and Phrases </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Conviction and Sentence </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The differences, thus, between Conviction and Sentence are that while a Conviction refers to the outcome of a criminal trial i.e. </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">the act of proving or declaring a person guilty</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> of a crime, a Sentence, on the other hand, is the formal declaration by a Court imposing a punishment on the person convicted of a </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">crime. Secondly, in the countries where criminal</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> trial is conducted by jury, a Conviction is a result of the verdict of a Judge and/or jury and, in contrast, a Sentence is typically ordered by a Judge and, thirdly, the Court cannot order a Sentence unless the person has been found guilty or convicted and, therefore, a Conviction must precede a Sentence.           . . . (13)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 426(1)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">From the wordings of the above provisions of Section 426(1) of the CrPC, it is explicit that the appellate Court as well as the High Court Division is invested with the power to </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">suspend the execution of the Sentence or Order</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> against which appeal has been preferred. It is, thus, crystal clear that the above quoted Section 426(1) of the CrPC envisages ‘suspension of execution of Sentence’; it does not state about ‘suspension of Sentence’ or ‘suspension of Conviction.                                       . . . (15)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 426(1)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">When a convicted-person is sentenced to death and, thereafter, the said convict, upon preferring appeal, is enlarged on bail or because of pending the death reference the death of the convict is not taking place, it amounts to ‘suspension of execution of the Sentence.  . . . (15)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 426</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 105%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">From concurrent reading of all the sub-Sections of Section 426 of the CrPC, we hold that the Legislature has meant that the Sentence may be suspended upon the satisfaction of the Court inasmuch as sub-Sections (2A) and (2B) having been subsequently incorporated in Section 426 of the CrPC by the Legislature by the amendments of the CrPC in the years 1945 (Act No. 2 of 1945) and 1946 (Act No. 4 of 1946) respectively, the literal meaning of the amended provisions as to ‘suspension of Sentence’ shall also be taken in the expression ‘suspension of execution of </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">Sentence’, so as to avoid any conflict between</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;"> these two phraseologies, particularly when the Marginal Heading of Section 426 of the CrPC clearly suggests that the provision of Section 426 of the CrPC is with regard to suspension of Sentence and releasing on bail pending appeal.    . . . (17)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Words and Phrases </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Suspension</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Suspension of execution of Sentence’ means ‘suspension of Sentence’. That is to say and conclude that the Sentence can be suspended.                             . . . (18)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Words and Phrases </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Conviction </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Conviction does not have the feature to be executable. Conviction is merely the findings of the Court. Because of securing suspension of Sentence, thus, Conviction does not go away or does not become suspended. Conviction remains intact until set aside on appeal. . . . (19)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Interpretation of Statute</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">When any statute prescribes Conviction as a </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">disqualification for contesting the local/ national</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> elections, for applying in any Government/ </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">non-Government service, for holding /remaining/</span></strong> <strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">continuing in any Government/non-Government</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> post, with the above civil consequences it acquires the feature of execution and, thereby, it operates in its full rigour until and unless its operation is stayed by the appellate Court or the High Court Division.   . . . (19)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Section 426</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">An order of suspension of Sentence is not capable of wiping out the Conviction. But, stay of order of Conviction results in rendering the impugned order of Conviction and Sentence temporarily inoperative and, as such, the same does not operate as a disqualification. . . . (19)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Section 426</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">In our way of scrutiny of the provisions of Section 426 of the CrPC, we did not find any hint in the aforesaid provision empowering any Court to suspend Conviction and, thus, we hold that in the backdrop of absence of the word ‘Conviction’ in the provision of Section 426 of the CrPC, Conviction cannot be suspended by any Court in adjudication upon an application under Section 426 of the CrPC.   . . .(20)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Sections 426(2) and 561 A</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The High Court Division may grant stay of Conviction under Sections 561A read with Section 426(2) of the CrPC only in exceptional and rare circumstances where non-grant of stay would lead to injustice and irreversible consequences.                                   . . . (21)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Sections 426(2) and 561 A</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">When a convict-appellant is debarred by a special law to contest the election because of operation of Conviction and Sentence, we hold that the convict-appellant must file a separate application for staying operation of the Conviction under Sections 426(2) read with Section 561A of the CrPC. The convict-appellant, in that event, is required to draw attention of the High Court Division to specific circumstances and s/he must take ground that for securing ends of justice, s/he has taken recourse to the power of the High Court Division under Section 561A of the CrPC coupled with making specific prayer for stay of operation of Conviction, not the suspension of Conviction.                                                           . . . (21)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Interpretation of Statute</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Upon obtaining bail from the appellate Court/High Court, although the convict-appellant’s Sentence becomes suspended, </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">but Conviction having remained intact, there</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> is no scope to continue the presumption of </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">innocence. However, in conducting the appeal,</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> the convict appellant is entitled to enjoy the advantage of treating her/his appeal as </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">continuation of trial, notwithstanding her/his</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> status of remaining a convicted person from the perspective of </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">presumption. Thus, appeal, as the continuation</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> of the trial, would not <em>ipso facto</em> bear the notion of remaining innocent until disposal of appeal.     . . . (22)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Constitution of Bangladesh, 1972</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Article 109</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 426(1)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">When the appellate Court would receive an application under Section 426 (1) of the CrPC, the Court shall first endeavour to dispose of the appeal on an urgent basis.</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The appellate Court should reject the application under Section 426(1) of the CrPC if the convict-appellant purposefully refrains from resorting to this provision at the earliest opportunity of starting the operation of the civil consequence and approaches the appellate Court only at the fag end of the purpose/cause/event for which s/he requires suspension of Sentence.</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">The lower appellate Court is empowered to suspend the Sentence only. The lower appellate Court is not competent to suspend/ stay operation of the Conviction.            . . . (27)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Rama Narang Vs. Ramesh Narang, (1995) 2 SCC 513; Navjot Singh Sidhu Vs. State of Punjab, AIR 2007 SC 1003;</span></em></strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;"> <strong>State of TN Vs. Jaganathan, AIR 1996 (SC) 2449;</strong> <strong>State of Haryana Vs. Hasmat, 2004 CRI.L.J, 3840 (Supreme Court);</strong> <strong>BR Kapur Vs. State of TN, (2001) 7 SCC 231 and Union of India Vs. Ramesh Kumar, (1997) 7 SCC 514 ref.</strong></span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Abdur Rob Chowdhury, Senior Advocate with </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Mr.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> Md.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> Shibbir Ahmed, Advocate,</span></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">. . .For the petitioner,</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Mr.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> Md.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> Khurshedul Alam, D.A.G </span></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . For the State.</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Probir Neogi, Senior Advocate</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. SM Shahjahan and </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Khurshid Alam Khan, Advocates</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . Amici Curiae</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">JUDGMENT</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">Muhammad Khurshid Alam Sarkar, J:</span></u></strong> <span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">On an</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> application under Section 426(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (CrPC) filed by the convict-applicant (hereinafter referred to as ‘the applicant’), this Rule was issued on 20.03.2017 calling upon the opposite party to show cause as to why the Conviction and Sentence imposed on the applicant in T.R. case no. 244 of 2003, arising out of G.R. case no. 4355 of 2003, should not be suspended during pendency of the Criminal Appeal no. 701 of 2003, which is now pending before the Court of Special Sessions Judge no. 3 of Dhaka (Nari-O-Shishu Nirjaton Domon Special Tribunal no. 3 of Dhaka). </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 109%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 109%;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 109%;">The short facts, leading to issuance of the Rule, are that the applicant was convicted under Section 4 of the Ain Sringkhola Bighnokari (Druto Bichar) Ain, 2002 and was sentenced to suffer rigorous imprisonment for a period of 4 years and to pay a fine of Taka 1000 by the Druto Bichar Adalat no. 4, Dhaka (hereinafter referred to as the trial Court) by the Judgment and Order dated 15.11.2003. Against the said Conviction and Sentence, the applicant preferred this Criminal Appeal no. 701 of 2003 before the Court of Metropolitan Sessions Judge, Dhaka on 22.11.2003 who thereafter transferred the same to the Court of Special Sessions Judge of Dhaka, who is also in charge of the Nari-o-Shishu Nirjatan Doman Special Tribunal No. 3, Dhaka (shortly, the appellate Court). Thereafter, the applicant filed Criminal Miscellaneous Case no. 13383 of 2005 for bail before the High Court Division and he was granted bail on 27.07.2006. Then, the applicant filed an application under Section 426(1) of the CrPC before the appellate Court for suspension of Conviction and Sentence. The appellate Court, after hearing the application, rejected it vide Order dated 11.05.2011 without showing any reason. Against the said rejection order, an application under Section 426(2) of the CrPC was moved before the High Court Division and a Rule was issued upon the State on 15.05.2011 in tandem with an interim order of suspension of the Sentence for three months which was never extended. Later on, on 29.01.2017, the applicant eventually non-prosecuted the said Rule issued in Criminal Miscellaneous Case no. 12883 of 2011. Again, the applicant filed a second application under Section 426(1) of the CrPC before the appellate Court for suspension of Conviction and Sentence, and after hearing the application the appellate Court rejected the same on 02.03.2017 against which the petitioner filed this Miscellaneous Case under Section 426(2) of the CrPC praying for suspension of the operation of the said Judgment and Order of Conviction and Sentence dated 15.11.2003. Accordingly a Rule was issued by this Court. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">At the motion hearing, the learned Senior Advocate Mr. Abdur Rob Chowdhury had strenuously argued that if the Conviction and Sentence is not suspended, the applicant shall suffer irreparable loss and injury inasmuch as the applicant shall not be allowed to contest for the post of the Chairman in the ensuing Union Parishad election to be held on 16.04.2017, albeit there is a fair chance of being acquitted if the appeal is heard. Considering the exigency, the instant Rule was issued together with an ad-interim order of suspension of the above Sentence dated 15.11.2003 for a limited period only, in order to enable him to contest the election for the post of the Chairman of Kamaldia Union Parishad, Upazilla: Modhukhli under the District of Faridpur scheduled to be held on 16.04.2017. However, at the time of issuance of the Rule, the learned Advocate for the applicant and the learned Deputy Attorney General were notified that this Rule shall be heard at the earliest, preferably within 4-6 weeks, with the assistance of some Amici Curiae in an endeavour to settle the law-points/issues relating to the provisions of Section 426 of the CrPC, for, although this Court is very often faced with similar applications but there had hardly been any occasion for this Court to lay down clear-cut guidelines for dealing with any application seeking suspension of any Conviction and Sentence. Accordingly, Mr. Probir Neogi, the learned Senior Advocate, Mr. SM Shahjahan and Mr. Khurshid Alam Khan, the learned Advocates of this Court, were asked to assist this Court in adjudication upon the legal issues, which have arisen in this case being pertinent to the provisions of Section 426 of the CrPC. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">When the Rule became matured for hearing and the matter appeared in the list under the heading “For Hearing”, no one turned up on behalf of the applicant to attend the hearing of this Rule. However, considering the importance of the issue involved in the Rule, this Court decided to hear the learned Amici Curiae and the learned Deputy Attorney General.   </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Probir Naogi, the learned Senior Advocate appears as an Amicus Curiae and, by taking us through the provisions of Section 426 of the CrPC, submits that any appellate Court as well as this Court, is well empowered to suspend the Sentence only, but not the Conviction. Secondly, it is the discretionary power of the appellate Court and the same should be exercised only upon receiving a formal application from the convict-appellant, he submits. Mr. Neogi submits that the power of suspending the Sentence must be exercised very judiciously only in a rare case where non-suspension shall result in a loss which cannot be compensated by anything and, finally, as he submits, if the High Court Division or the appellate Court decides to suspend the Sentence, the order must contain the reason/s for granting the application. In support of his submissions, Mr. Neogi places Paragraph 4.6 of the ‘Constitutional Law of Bangladesh’ written by Mahmudul Islam and also refers to the case of Rama Narang Vs Ramesh Narang (1995) 2 SCC 513 and Navjot Singh Sidhu Vs State of Punjab AIR2007 SC 1003.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. SM Shahjahan, the learned Advocate (Amicus Curiae) also, at first, places the provisions of Section 426 of the CrPC and submits that the appellate Court and the High Court Division are competent to allow any convict-appellant’s application for suspension of Sentence upon recording the reasonings thereto. By referring to the case of State of TN Vs Jaganathan AIR 1996 (SC) 2449, he submits that the Indian Supreme Court laid down the principle that the power of suspension of Sentence being a discretionary one for the appellate Court, the discretion must be exercised properly. Quoting the observation of the Indian Supreme Court from the case of State of Haryana Vs Hasmat 2004 CRI.L.J 3840 (Supreme Court), Mr. Shahjahan submits that only in exceptional cases the benefit of suspension of Sentence may be granted.  </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Khurshid Alam Khan, the learned Advocate (Amicus Curiae) takes us through the provisions of Section 426 of the CrPC and submits that the appellate Court is empowered by law to suspend only the execution of Sentence, but not the suspension of Sentence and, on this point, he refers to the case of BR Kapur Vs State of TN (2001) 7 SCC 231. Upon referring to the case of Union of India Vs Ramesh Kumar (1997) 7 SCC 514, he submits that by suspension of execution of Sentence under Section 426 of the CrPC an accused avoids undergoing Sentence pending the appeal, but the Conviction continues and is not obliterated. By placing an example before us, he submits that if any action is taken against a Government servant on misconduct which led to his Conviction by the Court of law, in spite of suspension of Sentence, the Conviction does not lose its efficacy. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Md. Khurshedul Alam, the learned Deputy Attorney General, while opts to adopt the submissions advanced by the learned Amici Curiae, adds a point that the presumption of innocence in favour of an accused comes to an end when a trial Court convicts an accused and sentences him. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">After hearing the learned Amici Curiae and the learned Deputy Attorney General and upon perusal of the applicant’s application, it appears to us that in order to properly deal with an application under Section 426 of the CrPC, the following legal issues are required to be addressed:- (i) what are the meanings of the words ‘Conviction’ and ‘Sentence’, (ii) what does mean by ‘suspension of execution of Sentence’ as it occurs in Section 426(1) of the CrPC, (iii) whether there is any difference between ‘suspension of execution of Sentence’ and ‘suspension of Sentence’, in other words, whether a Sentence can be suspended, (iv) whether Conviction is executable and suspendable and (v) whether the presumption of innocence of a person convicted and sentenced by a trial Court ends up with the pronouncement of Conviction and Sentence or it continues till the final verdict by the appellate Court/higher Court.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">There is no definition of ‘Conviction’ and ‘Sentence’ in the CrPC, or the Penal Code or, to our knowledge, in any other statute. Black’s Law Dictionary provides the meanings of the above two words as under:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Conviction: </span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The act or process of judicially finding someone guilty of a crime; the state of having been proved guilty. The judgment (as by a jury verdict) that a person is guilty of a crime. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Sentence:</span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> The judgment that a Court formally pronounces after finding a criminal defendant guilty; the punishment imposed on a criminal wrongdoer. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-outline-level: 2; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">11.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Literally the word ‘Conviction’ means the firm belief of a person in something. In our legal system, the term ‘Conviction’ is the outcome of the criminal prosecution that culminates in a decision of the Court. Conviction represents one of two possibilities that typically arise at the end of a criminal proceeding: either the accused will be found guilty or not guilty of the crime with which he/she is charged. Usually Conviction is perceived by the people as the state of being found or proven guilty or the act of proving or declaring a person guilty of a crime. By jogging any one’s mind back to one of the episodes of a legal TV series, particularly the scene of a criminal trial by the juror, the scene which would flash is that the juror stands up at the end and says “we find the accused guilty” or a Judge says ‘the accused has been found guilty of the crime’; this is a Conviction. Convictions are associated with criminal proceedings, as opposed to civil proceedings. Our criminal jurisprudence requires that to secure a Conviction, the prosecution has to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused committed the offence.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">12.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The word ‘Sentence’ is traditionally defined as the judicial determination and pronouncement of a punishment to be imposed on a person convicted of a crime. Once the accused has been found guilty of a crime, or rather convicted, the Court or Judge will formally declare the appropriate punishment to be imposed upon the person. The Court orders a Sentence based on the relevant law applicable to the particular crime. In our legal system, Sentence may take various forms; such as, Sentence of death, Sentence of imprisonment for life, Sentence of imprisonment for a fixed term, Sentence of forfeiture of property and Sentence of fine. These are specified by Section 53 of the Penal Code and also in other special laws. In other countries, Sentence also includes the community service, restitution, <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">rehabilitation programmes, deferred adjudication</span> or pre-trial diversion and probation. </span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Although there are no statutory laws or guidelines in our country to help the Judges in imposing the appropriate Sentence where the Penal Code or special statutes prescribe the maximum and minimum Sentence, a Court usually considers several <a href="http://criminal.findlaw.com/criminal-procedure/factors-considered-in-determining-sentences.html" title="Sentencing Factors"><span style="color: windowtext; text-decoration: none;">factors in determining a criminal Sentence</span></a>, including: whether the offender has any criminal history; whether the offender was the main offender or an abettor/accessory (someone who assists the main offender) or; whether the offender was under great personal stress or duress when he or she committed the crime; whether anyone was injured or the crime was particularly likely to result in injury; whether the offender was particularly cruel to a victim, or particularly destructive, vindictive, etc.; and whether the offender displayed remorse or regret. In our jurisdiction, there are two different types of Sentences, namely, <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">concurrent Sentences and consecutive Sentences</span> meaning that the multiple Sentences can be served concurrently (at the same time) or consecutively (one after another). In the developed/civilised countries, in cases where <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">the accused does not have a history of committing</span> crimes, a term of probation usually is ordered by the Court or the suspended Sentence is awarded. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-outline-level: 2; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">13.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The differences, thus, between Conviction and Sentence are that while a Conviction refers to the outcome of a criminal trial i.e. the act of proving or declaring a person guilty of a crime, a Sentence, on the other hand, is the formal declaration by a Court imposing a punishment on the person convicted of a crime.
