Secondly, in the countries where criminal trial is conducted by jury, a Conviction is a result of the verdict of a Judge and/or jury and, in contrast, a Sentence is typically ordered by a Judge and, thirdly, the Court cannot order a Sentence unless the person has been found guilty or convicted and, therefore, a Conviction must precede a Sentence. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">14.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">For examining the legal issue no. ii, namely, the scope of the expression ‘suspension of execution of Sentence’, we need to look into sub-Sections (1) &amp; (2) of Section 426 of the CrPC, which are quoted below: </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">426. (1) Pending any appeal by a convicted person, the Appellate Court may, for reasons to be recorded by it in writing, order that <u>the execution of the Sentence or order</u> appealed against be suspended and, also, if he is in confinement, that he be released on bail or on his own bond. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">(2) The power conferred by this section on an Appellate Court may be exercised also by the High Court Division in the case of any appeal by a convicted person to a Court subordinate thereto.</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">(Underlines added by us) </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">15.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">From the wordings of the above provisions of Section 426(1) of the CrPC, it is explicit that the appellate Court as well as the High Court Division is invested with the power to suspend the execution of the Sentence or Order against which appeal has been preferred. It is, thus, crystal clear that the above quoted Section 426(1) of the CrPC envisages ‘suspension of execution of Sentence’; it does not state about ‘suspension of Sentence’ or ‘suspension of Conviction’. When a convicted-person is sentenced to death and, thereafter, the said convict, upon preferring appeal, is enlarged on bail or because of pending the death reference the death of the convict is not taking place, it amounts to ‘suspension of execution of the Sentence’. Like-wise, when a convicted-person is sentenced to life imprisonment or to a fixed term imprisonment and, on appeal, instead of putting him in confinement, if he is released on bail, then the execution of the sentence remains suspended. Similarly, on preferring appeal, if the convict-appellant does not wish to comply with the order of payment of fine or forfeiture of the property and prays to the appellate Court for its non-payment or non-forfeiture and, accordingly, the appeal Court allows the prayer, then it is said that the execution of Sentence as to payment of fine or forfeiture is suspended. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">16.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In sequence to examination of the remaining legal issues, we may now see whether there is any difference between ‘suspension of execution of Sentence’ and ‘suspension of Sentence’, in other words, whether a Sentence can be suspended. For the said purpose, it would be profitable to look into the rest of the provisions of Section 426 of the CrPC, i.e. sub-Sections (2A)(B) and (3) which are reproduced below:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">426 </span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(2A) When any person is Sentenced to imprisonment for a term not exceeding one year by a Court, and an appeal lies from that Sentence, the Court may, if the convicted person satisfies the Court that he intends to present an appeal, order that he be released on bail for a period sufficient in the opinion of the Court to enable him to present the appeal and obtain the orders of the Appellate Court under sub-section (1) and <u>the Sentence of imprisonment shall, so long as he is so released on bail, be deemed to be suspended. </u></span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">(2B) Where High Court Division is satisfied that a convicted person has been granted special leave to appeal to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court against any Sentence which it has imposed or maintained, it may, if it so thinks fit, order that <u>pending the appeal the Sentence or order appealed against be suspended,</u> and also, if the said person is in confinement, that he be released on bail. </span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">(3) When the appellant is ultimately Sentenced to imprisonment, or transportation, the time during which he is so released shall be excluded in computing the term for which he is so sentenced. (underlined by us)</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">17.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">From a plain reading of sub-Sections (2A) and (2B) of Section 426 of the CrPC, it appears to us that Sentence is suspendable. Although in course of examining the provisions of Section 426 (1) of the CrPC, it was appearing that only ‘suspension of execution of Sentence’ is contemplated in the law, however, from concurrent reading of all the sub-Sections of Section 426 of the CrPC, we hold that the Legislature has meant that the Sentence may be suspended upon the satisfaction of the Court inasmuch as sub-Sections (2A) and (2B) having been subsequently incorporated in Section 426 of the CrPC by the Legislature by the amendments of the CrPC in the years 1945 (Act no. 2 of 1945) and 1946 (Act no. 4 and 1946) respectively, the literal meaning of the amended provisions as to ‘suspension of Sentence’ shall also be taken in the expression ‘suspension of execution of Sentence’, so as to avoid any conflict between these two phraseologies, particularly when the Marginal Heading of Section 426 of the CrPC clearly suggests that the provision of Section 426 of the CrPC is with regard to suspension of Sentence and releasing on bail pending appeal. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">18.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Therefore, although an ambiguity is apparent in the different sub-Sections of Section 426 of the CrPC as to having the meaning of ‘suspension of execution of Sentence’ and ‘suspension of Sentence’, in an effort to give coherent and workable meaning of the aforesaid expressions, this Court holds <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">that ‘suspension of execution of Sentence’ means</span> ‘suspension of Sentence’. That is to say and conclude that the Sentence can be suspended. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">19.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Now, we may take up the examination of the issue as to whether Conviction is executable and suspendable. As it has been found hereinbefore, in the course of examining the meaning of the words ‘Conviction’ &amp; ‘Sentence’, that Sentence is the corollary of the Conviction, the normal presumption would be that by dint of suspension of Sentence, the Conviction also becomes suspended. However, the above presumption is not correct inasmuch as while Sentence being something executable and, accordingly, without its suspension the death will take place or the convict will remain in confinement or the property would be forfeited or the fine is to be paid, Conviction does not have the feature to be executable. Conviction is merely the findings of the Court. Because of securing suspension of Sentence, thus, Conviction does not go away or does not become suspended. Conviction remains intact until set aside on appeal. This is the one side of the coin of Conviction. The other side of the coin of Conviction is that when any statute prescribes Conviction as a disqualification for contesting the local/national elections, for applying in any Government/non-Government service, for holding/remaining/continuing in any Government/non-Government post, with the above civil consequences it acquires the feature of execution and, thereby, it operates in its full rigour until and unless its operation is stayed by the appellate Court or the High Court Division. If in any Statute or Rules or Notifications, only Sentence is mentioned as a disqualification, Sentence requires to be stayed for that type of case as well. Sentence being the logical consequence of Conviction, the former does not become stayed without staying the <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">order of Conviction. There is difference between</span> suspension of Sentence (and Conviction) and stay operation of the Sentence (and Conviction). By simply suspending the order of Sentence, a convict-appellant shall not be able to revoke his disqualification, for, by suspending the Sentence, merely the execution of Sentence is suspended. Hence, an order of suspension of Sentence is not capable of wiping out the Conviction. But, stay of order of Conviction results in rendering the impugned order of Conviction and Sentence temporarily inoperative and, as such, the same does not operate as a disqualification.   </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 105%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">20.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 105%;">Now, the question comes up for consideration as to whether the appellate Court or the High Court Division is competent to suspend Conviction when a convict-appellant approaches the Court with an application under Section 426 of the CrPC. In our way of scrutiny of the provisions of Section 426 of the CrPC, we did not find any hint in the aforesaid provision empowering any Court to suspend Conviction and, thus, we hold that in the backdrop of absence of the word ‘Conviction’ in the provision of Section 426 of the CrPC, Conviction cannot be suspended by any Court in adjudication upon an application under Section 426 of the CrPC. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">21.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">While the lower appellate Court appears to be incompetent to suspend the operation of Conviction due to not being empowered by Section 426 of the CrPC or not being equipped by any other law, the High Court Division must not be seen to be lacking power to grant relief to a convict-appellant who is in dire need of an order of stay of operation of the Conviction towards enabling the convict to secure qualification for contesting the local/national elections, for applying in any Government/non-Government service, for holding/remaining in any Government/non-Government post etc. for a very short period, if the appeal cannot be disposed of quickly and the loss the convict-appellant would suffer is not compensable. However, the convict-appellant-applicant before the High Court Division must not be entitled to obtain a stay order from this Court until s/he satisfies that there was no fault on her part to dispose of the appeal and, further, s/he is willing to assist the appellate Court in disposal of the pending appeal within the shortest possible time. In other words, the High Court Division may grant stay of Conviction under Sections 561A read with Section 426(2) of the CrPC only in exceptional and rare circumstances where non-grant of stay would lead to injustice and irreversible consequences. When a convict-appellant is debarred by a special law to contest the election because of operation of Conviction and Sentence, we hold that the convict-appellant must file a separate application for staying operation of the Conviction under Sections 426(2) read with Section 561A of the CrPC. The convict-appellant, in that event, is required to draw attention of the High Court Division to specific circumstances and s/he must take ground that for securing ends of justice, s/he has taken recourse to the power of the High Court Division under Section 561A of the CrPC coupled with making specific prayer for stay of operation of Conviction, not the suspension of Conviction. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">22.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Let us now see whether presumption of innocence ends up with the pronouncement of Conviction and Sentence or whether it continues till the final verdict by the appellate Court/higher Court. In the criminal trial system of our jurisdiction, Conviction is the established findings of the trial Court on the criminal charge/s which was brought against an accused by the prosecution at the time of commencement of the trial of a criminal case, as has been held by us hereinbefore. Our criminal justice system allows an accused to seek discharge from the criminal charge/s brought against him at the stage of framing charge and, thereafter, also allows to pray for acquittal after the completion of prosecution evidence. After unsuccessfully exhausting the above two phases, an accused then finally waits for acquittal of the charge/s brought against him through receiving a full verdict. If the verdict contains the proof of charges brought against an accused, the trial Court convicts the accused, instead of acquitting him of the criminal charges and, consequent upon the said Conviction, the position of an accused converts into the status of a convict and, that is why, the Legislature purposefully opted to use the words in Section 426 of the CrPC ‘pending any appeal by a <u>convicted person</u>’. Once a Court convicts an accused and sentences to death/imprisonment for more than one year, upon preferring the appeal, the convict cannot claim bail as of right unless the Court is satisfied that there are good grounds/reasons to enlarge the convict-appellant on bail and, thereby, suspend the Sentence. A convict-appellant whose PC &amp; PR (PC stands for ‘Previous Character’, which is the description of previous conviction as per Regulation 272(b)(iv) of the PRB, 1943 and also the antecedents as per Regulation 272(b)(vii) of the PRB, 1943 of the Charge-sheeted person and ‘PR’ stands for ‘Police Registered’, which is the statements as to whether the Finger Print of the charge-sheeted person was taken previously in connection with any criminal case as per the requirement of Regulation 499 of the PRB, 1943) is clean and is convicted of a minor offence and is sentenced to less than ten years imprisonment and has co-operated with the trial Court in quick disposal of the trial by voluntarily surrendering before the trial Court and he, if was granted bail, has never misused the privilege of bail and, thereafter, at the appellate stage again he fully assists the Court in proceeding with his/her appeal by taking necessary steps, including by preparing Paper Book, but the appellate Court is not in a position to dispose of the appeal in near future, his/her application for bail pending appeal under Section 426 of the CrPC deserves positive consideration by the appellate Court or by the High Court Division. The Courts, however, should always be circumspect to entertain the bail application of a convict-appellant who is convicted of a heinous offence in addition to having had the record of previous Conviction. Upon obtaining bail from the appellate Court/High Court, although the convict-appellant’s Sentence becomes suspended, but Conviction having remained intact, there is no scope to continue the presumption of innocence. However, in conducting the appeal, the convict appellant is entitled to enjoy the advantage of treating her/his appeal as continuation of trial, notwithstanding her/his status of remaining a convicted person from the perspective of presumption. Thus, appeal, as the continuation of the trial, would not <em>ipso facto</em> bear the notion of remaining innocent until disposal of appeal. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 109%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 109%;">23.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 109%;">Now, we may revert to our case in hand and adjudicate this Rule applying the <em>ratio</em> laid down by us. In the present case, the convict-appellant-applicant wishes to contest the Union Parishad election for the post of Chairman, but due to the Conviction under Section 4 of Ain Sringkhoal Bighnokari (Druto Bichar) Ain, 2002 and Sentence of imprisonment for 4(four) years awarded by the trial Court, he is not qualified to do so and, under the circumstances, he prays for suspension of Conviction and Sentence. From the perusal of the application, it transpires that he has made his application under Section 426(2) of the CrPC. In fact, in most of such cases, the learned Advocate for the convict-appellant attempts to pray for suspending the Conviction and Sentence taking recourse to the provisions of Section 426 of the CrPC, which is completely an erroneous approach inasmuch as suspension of Conviction is not contemplated in Section 426 of the CrPC. From the plain reading of all sub-Sections of Section 426 of the CrPC, any one with ordinary prudence would see that law contemplates suspension of execution of Sentence and suspension of Sentence; not suspension of Conviction. Upon a minute reading of the entire provisions of Section 426 of the CrPC, which is comprised of 5 sub-Sections, and, thereby, examining the same as carried out hereinbefore, it is found that the provisions are primarily focused on and concerned with suspension of Sentence and granting bail to a convict who has already preferred or desires to prefer an appeal. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">24.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">As per the <em>ratio</em> laid down by us hereinbefore, the present convict-appellant-applicant is required to file an application under Section 426(2) read with 561A of the CrPC given that he wants to suspend not only his Sentence, but also his Conviction. Had it been his prayer that he wants to suspend the order of Sentence only, an application under Section 426(2) would have been fitted into towards mitigating his grievance albeit it would not help him remove his disqualification due to his Conviction remaining operative. The convict-appellant’s present application is, therefore, held to be not in form and misconceived one and, thus, the Rule is liable to be discharged only on this ground alone. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">25.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In any event, an application under Section 426 of the CrPC must not be treated as routine work by the lower appellate Court or the High Court Division. It is to be noted with emphasis that by the employment of the expression “the appellate Court <u>may</u>”, as it occurs in Section 426 (1) of the CrPC, the Legislature has made it clear that it is the discretion of the appellate Court and the High Court Division as to whether Sentence appealed against deserves to be suspended or not. Thus, it is not a matter of right for a convict-appellant to have execution of his Sentence suspended automatically by merely preferring an appeal. Therefore, a convict-appellant must file a separate application detailing the reason/s for suspension of Sentence. Upon minutely considering the ground/s taken by the convict-appellant, if the appellate Court/High Court Division proceeds towards taking a decision for suspending the Sentence, the Court is required to record its reasonings, for, one of the essential ingredients of Section 426 of the CrPC is the requirement for the appellate Court to record reasons in writing for ordering suspension of the Sentence. Therefore, the appellate Court is duty bound to objectively assess the matter and to record reasons for the conclusion that the case warrants suspension of Sentence. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">26.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In this application, no case is made out to satisfy us that the Conviction and Sentence would ultimately fail if the appeal is disposed of on merit. More so, the applicant-appears to have come with unclean hands, for, from the manner and style of handling his appeal, it is evident that he is not interested in disposing of the appeal which is pending before the lower appellate Court since the year 2003. Because of the applicant’s dubious role in dealing with his appeal, he does not deserve discretionary relief under Section 426 and 561A of the CrPC, even if this Court <em>suo  motu</em> converts the present application to be one under the above two Sections. Thus, this Rule is liable to be discharged. Given the pattern of conducting this case by this convict-appellant, it has been the bounden duty of this Court to pass an order of direction upon the concerned lower appellate Court to dispose of the appeal within the shortest possible time. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">27.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Before parting with this judgment, this Court feels it necessary to lay down some guidelines for the lower-appellate Court, as the part of this Court’s duty under Article 109 of the Constitution, to help the subordinate judiciary in conveniently and effectively dealing with the applications under Section 426(1) of the CrPC. The guidelines are set out below:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(1)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">   </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">When the appellate Court would receive an application under Section 426 (1) of the CrPC, the Court shall first endeavour to dispose of the appeal on an urgent basis. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(2)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">   </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The appellate Court should reject the application under Section 426(1) of the CrPC if the convict-appellant purposefully refrains from resorting to this provision at the earliest opportunity of starting the operation of the civil consequence and approaches the appellate Court only at the fag end of the purpose/cause/event for which s/he requires suspension of Sentence.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.25in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level2 lfo1; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .75in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">(3)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">   </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The lower appellate Court is empowered to suspend the Sentence only. The lower appellate Court is not competent to suspend/stay operation of the Conviction. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">28.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">In the result, the Rule is discharged without any order as to costs. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">29.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">The concerned appellate Court, namely, the learned Special Sessions Judge no. 3 of Dhaka (the learned Judge of the Nari-O-Shishu Nirjaton Domon Special Tribunal no. 3 of Dhaka) is directed to dispose of the Criminal Appeal no. 701 of 2003 arising out of TR Case no. 244 of 2003 corresponding to GR Case no. 4355 of 2003 within 6 (six) months from the date of receipt of this order and inform this Court accordingly by writing a letter to the Registrar of the High Court Division. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">30.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; line-height: 110%;">}</span></strong></span></p></td><td style="width: 93.55pt; padding: 0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt; height: 27.0pt;" width="125"><p class="CM11" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in .0001pt -.7pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Nazimuddin Mondal </span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="CM11" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt -.7pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">. . .<u>Appellant</u></span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="Default" style="text-align: center; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt -.7pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: windowtext;">=Versus=</span></strong></span></p><p class="Default" style="margin-left: -.7pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: windowtext;">Abul Kalam Azad and another </span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="Default" style="margin-left: -.7pt; text-align: right; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: windowtext;">. . . <u>Respondents</u></span></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Evidence Act (I of 1872)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Section 101</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.85pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">It is an established principle that the </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">plaintiff is bound to prove his case. The</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> plaintiff’s witnesses did not support his </span></strong><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">claim that he signed the document believing</span></strong> <strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">the same to be an agreement for a cinema</span></strong> <strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">hall. The plaintiff has therefore not satisfied</span></strong> <strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">his burden of proof under section 101 of the</span></strong><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Evidence Act. Moreover, the disputed deed shows that value of disputed land casts doubt on presumption of transfer by way of gift rather than it was deed of sale.         . . . (19 and 20)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.85pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">For the Appellant:</span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;"> Mr. Golam Arshed,</span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Advocate instructed by Mr. <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Md. Ferozur Rahman Advocate</span>-on-Record</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">For the Respondent No. 1:</span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;"> Mr. Md. </span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mahbub Uddin Khokon, Advocate, instructed by Mr. <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">Md. Taufique Hossain Advocate</span>-on-Record</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">For the Respondents No. 2:</span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Not represented</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.85pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">: </span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Not represented.  </span></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">JUDGMENT</span></u></strong></span></p><h4 style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><u><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-variant: small-caps;">Muhammad Imman Ali, J</span></u><u><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-variant: small-caps;">:</span></u> <span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-weight: normal;">This civil appeal by leave is directed against the judgement and order dated 29.08.2005 passed by a Single Bench of the High Court Division in Civil Revision No.6407 of 2001 making the Rule absolute.  </span></span></h4><p class="Style3" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The facts, relevant for disposal of the appeal, are that</span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> respondent No.1 as plaintiff instituted Other Class Suit No.13 of 1998in the court of Assistant Judge, Durgapur, Rajshahi for declaration that the deed of gift mentioned in schedule "kha" to the plaint in connection with the land mentioned in schedule "ka" to the plaint was false, fabricated and without any legal effect.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The plaintiff-respondent No.1 herein stated, <em>inter-alia</em>, that he was an illiterate person and only knew how to put his signature. The plaintiff along with pro-forma defendant No. 2 purchased the land mentioned in schedule “ka" to the plaint vide a registered sale deed No.5279 dated 14.11.1993 for a consideration of Tk.90,000/-.The possession of the land was duly handed over to them and they also got their names mutated on 01.11.1994 in Mutation Case No.463/IX-11/94-95. About three years before the filing of the suit, defendant No.2 along with his brother, i.e. defendant No.l (appellant herein)proposed to the plaintiff that if a Cinema Hall was established on the suit land it would bring them a huge sum of money as profit. Defendant No. 2 proposed that, in that event, they have to execute a deed for establishing a joint venture cinema hall. Placing reliance on their words the plaintiff accepted the said offer. Thereafter, the defendant took the plaintiff to the Registry Office and prepared a deed by a known deed writer, and in presence of their own witnesses took the signature of the plaintiff on a deed. After execution of the said deed, the plaintiff found that the defendants are no taking initiative to establish the said cinema hall. Thereafter, the plaintiff inquired into the matter at the Sub-Registry Office and on 10.02.1998 came to know that the defendants in collusion with each other created a false and fabricated deed of gift by using the signature of the petitioner with a statement that the plaintiff had gifted the suit land to defendant No.l. Hence he filed the suit for declaration that the said deed of gift is false, collusive and without consideration.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Defendant Nos.1-2 filed written statement denying the material allegations made in the plaint contending, <em>inter alia</em>, that the plaintiff-respondent No.1 herein is an educated person. The plaintiff and pro-forma defendant No.2 purchased the land mentioned in schedule "ka" of the plaint vide a registered sale deed being No.5279 dated 14.11.1993 for a consideration of Tk.90,000/-. The possession of the land was duly handed over to them and the said land was mutated on 01.11.1994 in Mutation Case No.463/IX-11,94-9G and the defendant respondent No.2 was jointly enjoying the land with the plaintiff. The suit land is adjacent to the house and the other lands of the defendant No.1, and he proposed to the plaintiff and the defendant respondent No.2 to hand over the land to him. The plaintiff as the boyhood friend of the defendant No.1 and defendant respondent No.2 as his brother willingly gifted the suit land to defendant No.1 vide registered deed of gift No.828 dated 12.02.1995. Thereafter, the plaintiff at the instance of the vested quarter instituted the suit to hamper the interest of defendant No.1.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">After hearing the parties and upon considering the evidence and materials on record, the learned Assistant Judge, Durgapur by his judgement and decree dated 12.02.1995 decreed the suit. Then defendant No.l filed Title Appeal No.189 of 1999 before the District Judge, Rajshahi. On transfer the said appeal was heard by the learned Subordinate Judge, Second Court, Rajshahi, who by his judgement and decree dated 05.08.2001 allowed the appeal setting aside the judgement and decree passed by the trial Court. </span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Against the aforesaid judgement and decree passed by the appellate Court, the plaintiff filed Civil Revision No. 6407 of 2001 before the High Court Division and obtained Rule, which upon hearing the parties was made absolute.  </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">Being aggrieved by the said judgement and order of the High Court Division, Civil Petition for Leave to Appeal No.380 of 2008 was filed by defendant No.1 and leave was granted to consider the following grounds: </span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">“I. That </span><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">plaintiff respondent filed a suit for declaration that the deed of gift dated 12.02.1995 given by the plaintiff-respondent to the defendant petitioner is not binding upon the plaintiff respondent as he has not given any deed of gift rather he has executed a deed for establishing Cinema Hall; that this being the fact, the High Court Division ought to have dismissed the appeal as the simple suit for declaration is not maintainable without a prayer for consequential relief as the same is barred by the provision of section 39 of the Specific Relief Act.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">II. That the suit is for simple declaration that the deed dated 12.02.1995 is not binding upon the plaintiff and the cancellation of the said deed and a payment of <em>ad-valorem</em> court fee is quite distinguishable with each other and as such the  appellate Court erred in law and fact in allowing the passing an order of payment of <em>ad-valorem</em> court fee, inasmuch as the question of limitation is involved as per the provision of article 91 of the Limitation Act, which is a question of law and fact and as such arrived at erroneous decision in decreeing the suit giving opportunity to make payment of <em>ad-valorem</em> court fee.</span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">Mr. Golam Arshed, learned Advocate appearing on behalf the appellant made submissions in line with the grounds upon which leave was granted. He further submitted that the plaintiff falsely stated that two persons purchased the land and that it was mutated by two persons. In fact, the land was purchased by three persons, including the appellant and the mutation was in the names of all three purchasers. The actual fact is that the land in dispute is adjacent to the land of defendant No.1 and the plaintiff sold the land to him, but because of their close friendship and in order to save on stamp duty they agreed to show the transfer as a gift. This was borne out by the evidence on record, but the High Court Division erred in not considering this aspect. He further submitted that the plaintiff was not able to prove that he signed the papers believing that it was an agreement and not a deed of gift. The learned Advocate also submitted that the suit for cancellation only ought to have been filed within three years, whereas the instant suit was filed beyond the period of limitation.</span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">Mr. Md. Mahbub Uddin Khokon, learned Advocate appearing for respondent No. 1 made submissions in support of the impugned judgement and order of the High Court Division. In addition, the learned advocate placed before us the following grounds: </span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span class="FontStyle11" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">“I. Because, the learned Appellate Court below failed to consider that the learned Assistant Judge, Durgapur in his aforesaid Judgement and Decree correctly summarized the case of the plaintiff -present respondent and appreciated the corroboration of the statement of witnesses produced by the plaintiff-present respondent and as such the appeal should be dismissed.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span class="FontStyle11" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">II. Because, the learned Appellate Court below in his Judgement and Decree failed to consider the ingredients of Muslim Heba and as such the appeal should be dismissed.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span class="FontStyle11" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">III.     Because, the learned court below in his Judgement and Decree committed an error both in law and in facts not considering that the aforesaid deed in question was made as a part of conspiracy of the defendant-appellant and as such the appeal should be dismissed.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span class="FontStyle11" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">IV. Because, the learned court below failed to consider that in the trial the defendant-appellant failed to prove that the possession of the suit land was transferred to the respondent which is a mandatory part of Muslim Heba and as such the appeal should be dismissed.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span class="FontStyle11" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">V. Because, the learned appellate court failed to consider that in the trial court the defendant present appellant did not contradict that the plaintiff-present respondent is a man of 30/32 years and sound health and as such the learned trial Judge correctly appreciated that the question of Heba by the plaintiff present respondent does not arise and as such the appeal should be dismissed.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span class="FontStyle11" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">VI. Because, the learned appellate Court tailed to appreciate that in the trial the defendant present appellant failed to produce any independent credible D.W. to support their case which was correctly appreciated by the learned trial Judge and as such the appeal should be dismissed.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span class="FontStyle11" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">VII. Because, the learned court below failed to consider that the learned trial Judge correctly summarized that from the evidences adduced by the P.W.'s and D.W.'s it was clearly proved that there was a proposal from the defendant present appellant to establish a cinema hall in the suit land and the plaintiff present respondent signed the aforesaid deed relying upon the proposal of the defendant present appellant and as such the appeal should be dismissed.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span class="FontStyle11" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">VIII. Because, the learned appellate judge failed to consider that the learned trial Judge correctly appreciated that the evidence adduced by the D.W's it was submitted that the plaintiff present respondent has taken consideration against the aforesaid transfer which is a gross violation of Muslim Heba and as such  the appeal should be dismissed.</span></span></p><p class="Style1" style="text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-pagination: widow-orphan; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">X. Because, the learned appellate court below failed to consider that the aforesaid Heba Deed No. </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">282 </span></span><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">dated </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">12.02.95 </span></span><span class="FontStyle13"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">was collusive, fraudulent, concocted and no legal effect at all and as such the appeal should </span></span><span class="FontStyle14"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">be dismissed.”</span></span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></strong>We have considered the submissions of the learned Advocates for the parties concerned, perused the impugned judgement and other connected papers on record. </span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">11.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">Land measuring 79 decimals was purchased jointly by Nazimuddin Mondal (defendant No.1), Md. Shomsher Ali Mondal (defendant No.2) and Md. Abul Kalam Azad (the plaintiff) in equal share for Tk.90,000/-by registered deed No.5279 dated 14.11.1993. By deed No.828 dated 12.02.1995, two of the original purchasers, namely Shomsher Ali Mondal and Md. Abul Kalam Azad transferred their shares, i.e. 52</span><span lang="EN-GB">¾</span><span lang="EN-GB"> decimals out of the 79 decimals to Nazimuddin Mondal (the third of the joint owners). The transfer was shown as a gift, and yet the transfer was valued at Tk.3,000/-. Abul Kalam Azad as plaintiff filed the suit in respect of 26</span><span style="position: relative; top: 4.5pt;"><img height="20" src="file:///C:\DOCUME~1\User\LOCALS~1\Temp\msohtmlclip1\01\clip_image002.gif" width="11"/></span><span lang="EN-GB"> decimals, i.e. his share of the land transferred, claiming that he did not intend to transfer the land by way of gift and that he signed the papers under the impression that he was entering a joint venture for opening a cinema hall.</span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">12.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">We find from the evidence that Shomsher Ali-defendent No.2, who deposed as D.W.2, is the brother of defendant No.1 and also a joint owner of the property. He stated that he along with the plaintiff and defendant No.1 jointly purchased 79 decimals of land and they were in joint possession in equal share and on 12.02.1995 he and the plaintiff sold their respective shares of the said land to defendant No. 1. He also stated that at the time when they purchased the land his elder brother Nazim (defendant No.1) had said that if either the plaintiff or defendant No. 2 wished to sell their portion of the land, then to sell to him. Accordingly, he and the plaintiff agreed to sell to defendant No.1. </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">13.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">The fact that the land in question was sold and not gifted to defendant No.1 was supported by the evidence of D.W.3, who stated in his deposition that earlier the entire 79 decimals of the suit land was in joint possession of all three, but subsequently Nazim(defendant No.1) enjoys the entire land. D.W. 3 stated in his cross-examination that Nazim paid Tk. 60,000/- to Kalam (plaintiff) and Shomsher Ali (defendant No. 2). D.W. 4 and D.W. 6 also supported the fact, that <a name="_GoBack"></a>the land was sold and they were both present at the time of writing of the deed as well as when it was presented for registration. D.W. 6 admitted that he advised execution of a deed of gift rather than a deed of sale in order to save stamp duty.  </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">14.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">The trial Court decreed the suit disbelieving defendant No.1 on the ground that in his plaint he had claimed that the deed in question was a deed of gift, whereas in his deposition he claimed that the transaction was one of sale. The trial Court observed that the written statement, deposition in chief and cross-examination were contradictory and hence not acceptable. The trial Court also discarded the evidence of D.W.3 and D.W.4 on the ground that they both deposed that the land was sold, whereas deed No.828 shows that it is a deed of gift.</span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">15.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">The appellate Court noted that the plaintiff suppressed the fact that the three of them together purchased the suit land and only disclosed that he and defendant No. 2 purchased the land by deed No.5279 dated 14.11.1993. The appellate Court further observed that the plaintiff himself went to the Sub-registry Office when all three together purchased the land from Ashek Ali and, he therefore, would know the difference between a deed of agreement and a deed of gift. The appellate Court also noted that from the signatures of the plaintiff it appeared that the plaintiff was an educated person. However, upon assessment of the evidence on record the appellate Court concluded that the story of a deed of gift was not believable. On the other hand the appellate Court accepted that the plaintiff and defendant No.2 sold the suit land to defendant No.1, but in order to save on stamp duty they created a deed of gift. </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">16.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">The appellate Court also considered that since the plaintiff is himself a party to the deed, he ought to have prayed for cancellation of the deed, and that a suit for simple declaration is not maintainable. </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: normal; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">17.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">The High Court Division did not specifically refer to the findings and observations of the appellate Court apart from noticing that the Subordinate Judge was in error in placing reliance on the contradictory statements of the D.Ws, who made statements beyond pleading. The High Court Division accepted that it was not enough to pray for declaration that the impugned deed of gift was collusive, fraudulent, illegal and ineffective and that cancellation of the impugned deed was the proper relief under section 39 of the Specific Relief Act. Accordingly, the High Court Division restored the judgement and decree of the trial Court with a direction upon the plaintiff to pay <em>ad valorem </em>court fee. </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">18.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">From the evidence and materials on record we find that the plaintiff has not been altogether honest in his claim regarding the purchase of the 79 decimals of land by deed No. 5270 dated 14.10.1993. He consistently claimed that two persons purchased the land in question, whereas the deed shows that the land was purchased jointly by three persons. He suppressed the fact that defendant No.1 was a joint owner of the suit land. It is also hard to believe that the plaintiff considered that he was signing a deed of agreement for a cinema hall, which in fact does not require registration. </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">19.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">It is an established principle that the plaintiff is bound to prove his case. The plaintiff’s witnesses did not support his claim that he signed the document believing the same to be an agreement for a cinema hall. The plaintiff has therefore not satisfied his burden of proof under section 101 of the Evidence Act. Moreover, the disputed deed shows that the land was valued at Tk.3000/- which casts doubt on the claim that the transfer was by way of gift.                 </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">20.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">The High Court Division correctly found that the transaction was a sale and not a gift, but then erred in not concluding that consequently the plaintiff’s claim of the deed being a deed of gift was not proved. The plaintiff had to prove that he signed the papers believing that he was signing an agreement for the cinema hall and not a deed of gift. But none of the plaintiff’s witnesses supported the plaintiff’s claim. Hence, the plaintiff’s case was not proved. Thus the impugned judgement and order cannot be sustained. </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN-GB">21.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">The evidence on record unquestionably discloses that the transaction was one of sale. It is equally evident that the requisite stamp duties were not paid at the time of registering the deed in question.  </span></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong>22.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></strong><span lang="EN-GB">In view of the above discussion, we are of the opinion that the plaintiff did not prove his case in accordance with law. A</span>accordingly, the appeal is allowed, however, without any order as to costs. The impugned judgement and order of the High Court Division is set aside. </span></p><p class="Default" style="text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Ed. </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoListParagraph" style="text-align: justify; line-height: normal; tab-stops: 27.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"> </span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><u><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; font-variant: small-caps;">Civil Appea</span></u></strong></a><strong><u><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 11pt; font-variant: small-caps;">l No. 301 of  2009</span></u></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span lang="EN-GB" style="font-size: 9pt;">(From the judgement and order dated 29<sup>th </sup>of August, 2005 passed by the High Court Division in Civil Revision No 6407 of 2001).</span></span></p></div></div></div></div>
571	<h2 class="blog_entry-title">The State Vs. Nayan and another 2017 (2) LNJ (AD) 126</h2>

2017</p><p><b>Appellant:</b>  The State</p><p><b>Respondent:</b>  Nayan and another</p><p><b>Subject:</b>  Criminal Law</p><p><b>Delivery Date:</b>  2017-12-17</p><!DOCTYPE html><p><!-- [if gte mso <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Shading Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="72" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful List Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="73" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Colorful Grid Accent 2"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="60" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Shading Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="61" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light List Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64"
